user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_Lock_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_Lock_Impl(void)
{
    int status;

    status = pthread_mutex_lock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_lock: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * Temporarily Disable/Defer thread cancellation.
         * Note that OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl() calls write() which is a cancellation point.
         * So if this calling task is canceled, it risks leaving the BSP locked.
         */
        pthread_setcancelstate(PTHREAD_CANCEL_DISABLE, &OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_BSP_Lock_Impl:
#define BSP_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobalData_t OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
pthread_setcancelstate(PTHREAD_CANCEL_DISABLE, &OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The call pthread_setcancelstate(...) is executed in the else branch when status >= 0. Since pthread_mutex_lock() returns 0 on success, that branch is reachable at runtime. (Note: the code has a logic bug — it checks status < 0 whereas POSIX pthread_mutex_lock() returns positive error codes on failure — but this makes the if-branch less likely to be taken, not the else branch unreachable. The BSP_DEBUG macro expanding to nothing does not make the else branch unreachable.)
